lines.text: In five minutes, I'll have you as sober as I am.
[stumbles into clothes rack, knocking it over]
I was kissed by a Spaniard once... now look at me!
Oh, Terry! Say, do you want to go to that funny little chop suey joint out of town, near abouts?
Say, where's Terry? Did you lose him in that chop suey joint?
Oh, I guess he couldn't find the place. He'll maybe wind up in some chink laundry lookin' for me.
Well, I hope you're satisfied.
[Sarcastically]
You haven't made it very tough for me. Now I've got to wire the home office and get a new leading lady. And I hope she isn't a blonde.
You're too good hearted. If you want a woman to stick by ya - to be crazy about ya - be indifferent to her. Don't show her too much affection.
Carlie, that's a great idea. The next woman I fall in love with, I'm gonna - pop her - right on the nose. That's what I'm gonna do.
Same old Daph.
Oh, same old Don. Still making love to every girl that you meet?
Oh, no. I miss one - occasionally.
Now, you two are absolutely crazy about each other - almost to the ga-ga point.
Now, in the second act, Terry goes into the army and follows you to France. And Carlie, here, loves Terry so much, that she follows him disguised as a donut. I mean, a doughboy.
I'll give Terry more air than Lindbergh needed to fly to Paris.

I've got you to think about. We've been partners too long. Battling through the small time, through the tough audiences, cheap theaters, playing a million benefits, living in left-handed boarding houses - until finally we built ourselves into a stand-up two act and, now, some smart-cracking dame has come along and tried to kid somebody. And split us up! I-I ought to pop her on the nose!
Why, I don't know whether its the light or the climate or what it is? But, you look like a little school girl sitting there.
I'd be like a boat without a rudder without you.
Somebody put me on a merry-go-round and forgot to take me off. Whoopee!
You haven't got the backbone of a jellyfish!
